objdescid.origination: William Blakeauthor, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.publisher: William Blake Blake's name is given as the "printer" on the title page to *Songs of Innocence*, but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not printed in the work, but Blake lived in London during the composition and etching of *Songs of Innocence*. When this copy was printed, Blake was probably living in Felpham, Sussex, but it is possible that it was not printed and/or colored until he returned to London in autumn 1803.
imprint.date: 1789The 1789 date appears on Object 2 (Bentley Plate 3), the title page to *Songs of Innocence*.

objinfo.numberobj: 26This copy lacks Bentley Plates 6 and 7, "The Ecchoing Green." See the note on Penned Numbers, below.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 12.3 x 7.7 cm. and 10.9 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: 19.4 x 13.7 cm.Object 18 (Bentley Plate 20) is trimmed to 19.4 x 13.0 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief and white-line etching with hand coloringThe light pencil lines covering part of the texts of Objects 16 and 17 (Bentley Plates 19 and 18) were almost certainly not inscribed by Blake.
objinfo.watermark: BUTTANSHAW | 18[ ]The full watermark date is probably 1802. The mark appears only in Objects 7, 20, and 22 (Bentley Plates 10, 26, and 17).
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-4, 7-28 top rightThe absence of plates numbered 5 and 6 suggests that two plates were removed from this copy after Blake had numbered them. These removed plates were very probably Bentley Plates 6 and 7, the two plates of "The Ecchoing Green." These two plates were missing when this copy was sold at auction in 1936; see the note on Provenance, below.
objinfo.binding: nineteenth-century half black roan over green marble-paper boards

provenance.name: Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas Library
provenance.note: Acquired at an unknown time, possibly directly from Blake, by Arthur Champernowne (1767-1819) of Dartington Hall, Devon; probably by inheritance to one of his three sons in 1819; probably one of Arthur Champernowne's grandsons by inheritance at an unknown time; sold by Arthur Champernowne's great-grandson, A. M. Champernowne, Sotheby's, 6 May 1936, lot 718, "26 plates" with "the two 'Ecchoing Green' plates...missing" (£180 to the dealer Jacob Schwartz); sold by Schwartz in 1937 to T. Edward Hanley; sold or given by Hanley to the University of Texas in 1965.

desc.objtitle:
Frontispiece to Songs of Innocence Songs of Innocence,
Object 1 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A long-haired partly nude male (in semi-transparent tights), holding a musical pipe, walks toward the viewer with his left leg forward. This shepherd-piper looks up to the right at a cherubic nude male(?) infant or child floating in a horizontal position on a light-colored cloud, seemingly bathed in light in this copy. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper. The plate is framed by trees on both sides. Overhead are either leafless branches against a dark sky or dark, leafy branches. Behind the piper are grazing sheep and, in the background, more trees. Dark shadows extend from the shepherd-piper's feet.

component.illusobjdesc: Dark shadows extend from the shepherd-piper's feet. There may be another shadow in the lower right corner.

A curly-haired partly nude male (in semi-transparent tights), holding a musical pipe, strides toward the viewer with his left leg forward. Both arms are bent at the elbow. The body of this shepherd-piper faces forward but he looks up to the right at a cherubic male child.

A muscular but cherubic nude male(?) infant or child with short and curly hair hovers in a horizontal position on a cloud above the head of a shepherd-piper. The child, with his arms raised horizontally, his hands raised with palms facing up and out, and his legs spread, looks down at the piper.

A cherubic male(?) child hovers on a cloud above the shepherd-piper's head. In this copy, the light-colored cloud seems bathed in light. Although the top of the plate is dominated by branches in most copies, the dark area just below the top margin of the plate might be a cloud or dark sky in this copy.
A flock of sheep grazes behind the shepherd-piper. Two in the front have their heads down.

Trees frame the plate on both sides. The tree on the left has a single trunk, while the two trees on the right intertwine. Overhead are either leafless branches against a dark sky or dark, leafy branches. There are more trees in the background.
The ground beneath the shepherd-piper would appear to be covered with grass.
A male shepherd holds a musical pipe.

desc.objtitle:
Title Page for Songs of Innocence,
Object 2 (Bentley 3, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a boy with short, curly hair; the child on the right, with long hair, is probably a girl. To the right of the group is a large apple(?) tree bearing fruit; around the trunk loosely spirals a vine. Various small figures can be seen among the letters of the title, including a piper wearing a broad-brimmed hat standing in the crook of the first letter of "Innocence" (line 4). Birds fly in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" and above the "N" in "SONGS" (line 2). Another bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence." The background landscape may include low hills in the distance. A slight rosy tint just above the hills hints at a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds a book that two children read.

In her lap a nurse or mother holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a male with short and curly hair looking down at the book. He wears at least a shirt, perhaps a gown.

In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the right, with long hair and wearing a gown, is probably a girl. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, with the forearm raised horizontally. Her left hand may be pointing to a passage in the book.
In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read or at least look at.
A nurse or mother sits in a chair that faces right.

To the right of the nurse or mother and two children is a large apple(?) tree, bearing fruit (around "of" in the title [line 3]); around its trunk loosely spirals a vine. The upper leaves on the right of the tree reach near the flame-like vegetative motifs springing from the letters of "SONGS" (leafy extensions of the initial "S," the "N," and the terminal "S" are particularly extravagant [line 2]).
There is a tree on the horizon, just right of the trunk of the large tree.
There may be a figure, facing left, sitting on the mid-stroke of the initial "S" in "SONGS." The figure's left(?) leg dangles below the letter.
In the "O" of "SONGS" (line 2) is a kneeling figure with arms raised in a curve at about 135 degrees. We probably see this figure from behind.
A tiny form, standing above the left vertical of the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2), might be either a cross or a human figure with arms raised at 45 degrees.
A standing, winged figure leans against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2). The figure may be looking down at and holding a book, reading or writing.
The figure leaning against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2) may be holding a book.
A tiny gowned(?) female(?) figure with at least the left arm raised vertically stands, facing left, in the "G" of "SONGS" (line 2).
There may be a seated figure, hunched over and facing right, in the lower curve of the final "S" of "SONGS" (line 2).
A male piper(?) with a broad-brimmed hat and holding a pipe to his mouth, stands facing left and leaning against the "I" of "Innocence" (line 4).
A bird flies upward in the sky beneath and to the left of the initial "S" in "SONGS" (line 2).
A bird flies upward on extended wings above the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2).
A bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence" (line 4).
The coloring of the landscape suggests some sort of vegetation, perhaps grass in the foreground.
The landscape may contain low hills in the distance. A slight rosy tint just above the hills hints at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: SONGS
of
Innocence
The Author & Printer WBlake

desc.objtitle:
Introduction,
Object 3 (Bentley 4, Erdman 4, Keynes 4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels (top left to bottom right): (1) two figures, the one on the left gowned and seated; (2) a running, leaping, nude figure; (3) a standing figure, looking down; (4) an indistinct standing(?) figure; (5) at top right, a flying bird with vegetation, perhaps tree limbs and leaves, above and below; (6) a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body, with arms crossed and possibly holding an infant; (7) a solitary standing female(?) figure wearing a bonnet, possibly sowing seeds, with three flying birds; (8) possibly one or two seated figures. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins leafy vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils, some of them (top, bottom) loopy, that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.

In the panel at top left there are two indistinct figures. The one on the left is gowned, seated, and facing right. The smaller figure to the right may be a standing child or a seated adult, again gowned, and possibly facing left.
In the second panel down from top left, a nude figure runs or leaps toward us with legs spread and arms raised to 135 degrees.
In the third panel down from top left is a standing figure with head lowered. The human figure may be indulging in some sort of agricultural activity.
There may be a standing figure in the panel lowest left.
In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree, above and below. There are three more birds in the third panel from the top on this side.
In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree, above and below.
In the second panel from top right is a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body, with arms crossed and possibly holding an infant.

In the third panel from top right is a solitary standing figure, possibly female wearing a bonnet, with three birds flying near. The figure's left arm may be raised at just under 45 degrees. The figure may be indulging in some sort of agricultural activity, such as sowing seeds.
There may be a seated figure—or possibly two such figures—in the lowest panel on the right, with prominent knees.
Blue, pink, and yellow wash within the text area and extending into the eight panels suggests the sky and a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Piping down the valleys wild.
Piping songs of pleasant glee
On a cloud I saw a child.
And he laughing said to me.
Pipe a song about a Lamb.
So I piped with merry chear,
Piper pipe that song again__
So I piped, he wept to hear.
Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe.
Sing thy songs of happy chear
So I sung the same again
While he wept with joy to hear
Piper sit thee down and write
In a book that all may read__
So he vanish'd from my sight.
And I pluck'd a hollow reed.
And I made a rural pen,
And I stain'd the water clear,
And I wrote my happy songs,
Every child may joy to hear

desc.objtitle:
The Shepherd,
Object 4 (Bentley 5, Erdman 5, Keynes 5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young, curly-haired male shepherd stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep. He holds a crook in his left hand; his shepherd's purse, or wallet, is visible near his right knee. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks straight ahead and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms (not colored in this copy) near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees and a hilltop in the background, where the light suggests that the time is sunrise or sunset. On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the light. Three smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird. There may be two even smaller birds perched on the limb below and to the right of those in flight.

component.illusobjdesc: A young male shepherd with short, curly hair stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep—perhaps looking at the sheep that lifts its head toward him. He holds a crook in his left hand; his purse is visible near his right knee. His arms are bent at the elbow, with his body facing forward but his head turned to the left. He wears tights, although these are rather loose just above the knees and look like a skirt.

A shepherd watches his grazing flock of sheep. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks straight ahead and beside it another sheep—possibly one of the "lambs" of line 7—lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. The rest of the grazing sheep appear to have their heads lowered to the ground, including several in the front and the ram.

Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees in the background.
The coloring of the ground indicates grass.
Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom.
There are trees and a hilltop in the background, where the light suggests that the time is sunrise or sunset.
There are trees and a hilltop in the background, where the light suggests that the time is sunrise or sunset.

On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the sky. Three much smaller birds soar to the right of the large one. There may be two even smaller birds perched on the limb below and to the right of those in flight.
The shepherd's purse is visible beside his right knee.
The shepherd holds a crook.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves or flowers branches off the "T" in "The" in the title (line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves or flowers branches off the "T" in "The" in the title (line 2).

lg.l: How sweet is the Shepherds sweet lot,
From the morn to the evening he strays;
He shall follow his sheep all the day
And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
For he hears the lambs innocent call.
And he hears the ewes tender reply.
He is watchful while they are in peace.
For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

desc.objtitle:
Infant Joy,
Object 5 (Bentley 25, Erdman 25, Keynes 25)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her small wings is marked with a dot. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7). A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the center-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.

component.illusobjdesc: Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Her wings are like those of a butterfly. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7).

Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a drooping closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the middle-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.
Blue and gray tinting at top and bottom suggests sky; faint yellow and orange/pink tinting upper left hints at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: I have no name
I am but two days old.__
What shall I call thee?
I happy am
Joy is my name,__
Sweet joy befall thee!
Pretty joy!
Sweet joy but two days old,
Sweet joy I call thee;
Thou dost smile.
I sing the while
Sweet joy befall thee.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Black Boy,
Object 6 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At dawn, an adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child who points upward with his left hand. With her right hand she reaches across her lap to point at “the rising sun” (line 11). Presumably they correspond to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) and "Little Black Boy" (title [line 2]) of the text. They are both dark of skin. The pair sits under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. A vine winds around the tree trunk. A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller, but also entwined by a vine, grows up the right margin and arches over the sun. A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. "The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon in a rosy and golden sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Under a tree, a long-haired, dark-skinned adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child. With her right hand she reaches across her lap to point at the sun. Presumably she corresponds to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) of the text.

Under a tree, an adult female sits facing a kneeling(?) child, apparently nude and male with curly hair, who points upward with his left hand and one raised finger. Presumably he is the "Little Black Boy" of the text (line 2). They are both dark of skin.
The mother and child sit under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother.
A twining vine winds around the tree trunk on the left.
>"The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon in a golden and rosy sky.
A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller than the one on the left, grows up the right margin and arches over the rising sun.
A twining vine winds around the trunk of the smaller tree on the right.
A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title (line 2). From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above ground level, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below line 13 of the text. Another vine with loops and leaves fills the right margin above. The capital letters of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black." A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree." The blue, rose, and yellow tinting of the text area suggests sky at sunrise.

component.illusobjdesc: The blue, rose, and yellow tinting of the text area suggests sky at sunrise.

Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title (line 2). From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above ground level, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below the end of line 13. One extension of this vine descends in a spiral in the plate's lower right corner. Above, another vine with loops and leaves fills the remaining spaces right of the text. The capital letters of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black."
A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree."

lg.l: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
And I am black, but O! my soul is white.
White as an angel is the English child:
But I am black as if bereav'd of light.
My mother taught me underneath a tree
And sitting down before the heat of day.
She took me on her lap and kissed me,
And pointing to the east began to say.
Look on the rising sun: there God does live
And gives his light. and gives his heat away.
And flowers and trees and beasts and men recieve
Comfort in morning joy in the noon day.
And we are put on earth a little space..
That we may learn to bear the beams of love.
And these black bodies and this sun-burnt face
Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Black Boy (continued),
Object 7 (Bentley 10, Erdman 10, Keynes 10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The elements of the design combine and develop a selection of those on the previous plate. Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank. There is a halo around his head. Two nude boys—the boy on the left dark of skin and his companion pale of skin—stand in front of him. One, probably the "little English boy" (line 7) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem, stands at Jesus's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Jesus, who looks down at him. The other boy, probably the little black boy from the previous plate, stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12). All three are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. Its roots may be partially exposed on the bank to the right. A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy. A river runs at the foot of the plate. A vine or plant grows lower left. A vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. The tree is backed by leafy plants or trees. Blue and gray washes in the text area, combined with a hint of pink to the right of the tree, suggest a sky and clouds, possibly a somewhat dark sky just before sunrise or just after sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with long hair, beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank with two children standing in front of him. He looks down at the child at his knees. There is a halo around his head. Holding his crook between his legs and across his left shoulder, he rests his left arm on his lap with his hand on his knee. His left foot is exposed.

To the left of the English boy and Christ, a second nude child with short, curly hair, probably the dark-skinned little black boy from the previous plate, stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12).

The nude and long-haired "little English boy" (line 7) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem stands at Christ's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Christ, who looks down at him. The boy's right leg is extended backward.
A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy.
A few low hills fill the horizon above the sheep.
All three of the figures are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. Its roots may be partially exposed on the bank to the right.
A vine or plant grows lower left. It may have leaves on the tips of its branches.
A double vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. The larger stem bears leaves or flowers.
The willow-like tree is backed by leafy plants or trees.
Jesus sits on a bank in which a tree and double vine are rooted.
A river runs below the figures, just above the bottom margin of the plate.
Blue and gray washes in the text area, combined with a hint of pink to the right of the tree, suggest a sky and clouds, possibly a somewhat dark sky just before sunrise or just after sunset.
In a sitting position, Christ holds a shepherd's crook between his legs and across his left shoulder.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The detached vine is flame-like at the top and in the left margin is intertwined with another vine. The vine on the right sends out two shoots, possibly including one or two flowers, to the right of line 6.

component.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The detached vine is flame-like at the top and in the left margin is intertwined with another vine. The vine on the right send out two shoots, possibly including one or two flowers, to the right of line 6.

lg.l: For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear
The cloud will vanish we shall hear his voice.
Saying: come out from the grove my love & care.
And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice.
Thus did my mother say and kissed me.
And thus I say to little English boy.
When I from black and he from white cloud free,
And round the tent of God like lambs we joy:
I'll shade him from the heat till he can bear,
To lean in joy upon our fathers knee.
And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair.
And be like him and he will then love me.

desc.objtitle:
On Anothers Sorrow On Another's Sorrow,
Object 8 (Bentley 27, Erdman 27, Keynes 27)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right edge of the plate. A vine grows up around its trunk. Clusters of grapes or flowers hang from the vine opposite stanzas 6 and 7. At the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near the bird with long tail feathers that ascends to the right of stanza 6. Other birds fly to the right of lines 4, 7, and 13. There may also be a bird perching on the branch to the right of line 6. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable (line 2). The left margin is dominated by a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree. A figure playing a pipe stands next to the right tree, lower left. A second figure climbs in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. There may also be a third figure with arms raised, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, although the figure merges with the tendrils in this copy. A fourth human form, left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised. Blue, yellow, and rose washes suggest the sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: There may be as many as four figures in the left margin. A figure, facing left, stands at the base of the tree on the left and plays a pipe. A second figure climbs in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. Perhaps a third, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, raises his arms as if in supplication—although the figure is hard to separate from the vines in this copy. The final figure, clearly represented left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised vertically.
A bird with long tail feathers ascends to the right of stanza 6. Three other birds fly to the right of lines 4, 7, and 13. There may also be a bird perching on the branch to the right of line 6.

A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right margin. A vine grows up its trunk. Clusters of grapes or flowers hang from the vine opposite stanzas 6 and 7. At the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near stanza 6. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable (line 2). In the left margin is a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree.
Blue, rose, and yellow washes suggest the sky at sunrise or sunset.
The standing figure at bottom left is playing a pipe.

lg.l: Can I see anothers woe.
And not be in sorrow too.
Can I see anothers grief.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child.
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
Pouring pity in their breast.
And not sit the cradle near
Weeping tear on infants tear.
And not sit both night & day.
Wiping all our tears away.
O! no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
He doth give his joy to all,
He becomes an infant small.
He becomes a man of woe
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not. thou canst sigh a sigh,
And thy maker is not by.

Think not, thou canst weep a tear,The second and third letters in the final word ("tear") were poorly printed and have been written over in pen and ink, probably by Blake. The final letter was also poorly printed, but not over-written.
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy.
That our grief he may destroy
Till our grief is fled & gone
He doth sit by us and moan

desc.objtitle:
Spring,
Object 9 (Bentley 22, Erdman 22, Keynes 22)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Sitting beneath the branches of a tree with its trunk behind her, a gowned woman with hair pulled back looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. She holds a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. Low hills define the horizon above the sheep. The yellow and rose coloring of the sky above the hills hints at a sunrise or sunset. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (Object 12, line 9).

component.illusobjdesc: Sitting to the right of a large tree trunk, a gowned woman with hair pulled back into a bun looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. Her right foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown. She holds a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap.

A seated woman holds her(?) short-haired nude infant, who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (Object 12, line 9).

A mother and her(?) infant overlook a flock of grazing sheep. In the final stanza of the poem, an infant or child speaks to a "Little Lamb," and this may be the small animal that raises its head toward the infant.
The horizon above the sheep is defined by low hills. Above, the yellow and rose coloring of the sky hints at a sunrise or sunset.
One branch of a leafy tree, its trunk just right of the left margin, arches over the woman and infant.
A bit of green coloring under the sheep's feet suggests grass.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" (line 2) and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and two tassels of grain. Another vine curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate. This vine ends in two tassels of grain as well. Two winged angels occupy this vegetation, one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe right of lines 3-4; the other reclining on one arm right of line 12.

component.illusobjdesc: Two winged angels with obscure features occupy the vegetation to the right of the text: one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe opposite lines 3-4; the other, wings outspread, reclining on one arm opposite line 12. The upper angel may be gowned, the lower nude.

Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" (line 2) and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and two tassels of grain. Another vine curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate. This vine ends in two tassels of grain as well.
The blue, rose, and yellow tinting of the text area suggests sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Sound the Flute!
Now it's mute.
Birds delight
Day and Night.
Nightingale
In the dale
Lark in Sky
Merrily(Year
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the
Little Boy
Full of joy.

desc.objtitle:
Spring (continued),
Object 10 (Bentley 23, Erdman 23, Keynes 23)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with curly hair reclines on grassy ground. With both hands the infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Two sheep also lie on the ground, left and right of the infant. He(?) may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (line 9). An uneven gray wash at bottom may indicate a river running below the child and animals (the river is more clearly defined in some other copies).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with short, curly hair (probably male) reclines, with his left leg crossed over his extended right leg, in the midst of a group of three sheep. With his left hand he touches the neck—and with his right the back—of a lamb to the left; the two of them look at one another. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (line 9).

An infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Grown sheep lie on the right and left; the one on the right faces forward while the one on the left appears to be watching the lamb and infant.
The ground may be covered with grass.
An uneven gray wash at bottom may indicate a river running below the child and animals (the river is more clearly defined in some other copies).
Wash in the text area and through the vignette below suggests the sky at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words (line 2, 9) of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two grain tassels grow from this framing vine. Two clusters of similar vegetation (one sprouting near the end of line 8, the other near the end of line 9) fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There is a figure associated with each cluster of vegetation in the right margin: below, a gowned angel with large wings sitting on a curve of the plant with her(?) knees drawn up and her head down; above, a gowned figure standing, with arms outspread, in a semi-circle made by the plant. Tassels grow from the clusters of vegetation also: to the right of lines 14-16, below the last two words in line 8, and right of lines 3-4.

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the first stanza, a gowned figure stands in a semi-circle made by a vine or leaf. Her(?) arms are outspread, partially hidden by the vine-like plant that circles around her. Her body may be twisting away from the viewer.
Right of the last stanza, a winged, gowned angel sits on a curve of the plant with her(?) legs drawn up and her head down, her body facing left.

Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words (lines 2, 9) of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two clusters of similar vegetation fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There are grain tassels at the right side of the lower vignette and to the right of lines 14-16, below the last two words in line 8, and to the right of lines 3-4.

lg.l: Little Girl
Sweet and small.
Cock does crow
So do you.
Merry voice
Infant noise
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the Year
Little Lamb
Here I am,
Come and lick
My white neck.
Let me pull
Your soft Wool.
Let me kiss
Your soft face.Year
Merrily Merrily we welcome in the

desc.objtitle:
Laughing Song,
Object 11 (Bentley 15, Erdman 15, Keynes 15)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eight figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation. Five figures sit behind the table, away from the viewer; the female at far right extends her arm to hold a drinking glass that rests on the table. Near the ends of the table on the front side, two other figures sit in chairs that are turned sideways, facing one another. Each figure holds a glass on the table. Between them stands an eighth figure, a male in tights. In upraised hands he holds a glass (right) and a plumed hat (left). The faces of all but one of the figures on the far side of the table are visible. The three figures on the near side face away from the viewer toward the rest of the company. The text mentions "green woods," "meadows," and a "table" in "the shade" (lines 3, 7, 11-12). The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the shadows on the ground, lower right.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center is a curly-haired male in tights standing poised and erect facing away from the viewer. His legs are spread; his right leg is straight, his left is extended left, the foot held with its toes pointed. His arms are bent and raised vertically. In his right hand is a wine glass or cup, in his left a hat with a plume. In the context of the poem his actions suggest that he may be singing.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far left is a female with curly(?) hair and wearing a long gown. Her left leg is extended slightly forward; her right leg is drawn back under her. Her right arm is extended to hold a glass that rests on the table. Her left arm rests on the back of her chair, and her body is twisted counterclockwise as if to face the female across the table from her.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far right is a short-haired male in tights. His left leg is extended forward and his foot is visible; his right leg is drawn back under him. His right arm is extended along the table surface to hold a glass; only the upper part of his left is visible near the back of the chair. His lower body faces left, with his torso facing forward and his head twisted clockwise to face the two females across the table.
Five figures are seated behind the table. The figure at far left seems to be a female in a hat with a round brim.
There would seem to be the head and upper body of a seated figure behind the table just above the right shoulder of the woman seated in a chair on the viewer's side of the table.

Five figures are seated behind the table. Third from the left appears to be a long-haired(?) female wearing a V-neck gown. Her head is turned right and tilted up. Her right arm is raised to 45 degrees, her left bent at the elbow.
Five figures are seated behind the table. Second from the right is a female in a high-waisted gown. Her hair is either short or pulled back. She faces forward.
Five figures are seated behind the table. At far right is a female wearing a hat with a round brim. At the end of an outstretched right arm she holds a glass that rests on the table.

Several figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation, probably trees. Though the vegetation is not clearly defined, the text mentions "meadows" and "green woods" (lines 7, 3). The trunk of a tree appears far right in this copy.
The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the dark shadows on the ground lower right and extending along the lower margin of the design.

In front of the table, near each end, two figures sit in symmetrically-placed chairs turned parallel with the table. The chairs have backs and rear legs integrated into a single convex curve. The front legs of the chair on the right curve forward to balance the curve of the rear legs.
Four figures hold drinking glasses. Three rest on the table; the fourth is in the right hand of the central standing figure.
There is a plumed hat with a round brim in the left hand of the central standing figure. The women at far left and far right sitting behind the table also have on round-brimmed hats.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decoration is marginal rather than strictly interlinear. Numerous birds, especially in the bottom margin, ornament areas around the text. There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing" (line 2), and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines (lines 13-14) and across the bottom. The text area is colored to suggest a cloudy(?) sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The text area is colored to suggest a cloudy(?) sky at sunrise or sunset.

Several birds of various sizes perch and fly on and among the vegetation. Around the title, to the left a bird with outspread wings ascends vertically; another glides over "Song" (line 2); and at the right a third dives. In the right margin, after "shade" (line 11), a tiny bird ascends steeply. The small winged creature farther to the right may be another bird or an insect. Across the bottom of the plate are seven other birds (left to right): two flying above the vine, with outspread wings and forked tails, the right one ascending; below the vine a third, descending; a fourth, with forked tail, perching on the vine; to its right, above the vine a fifth bird flying, and below the vine, a sixth ascending and, finally, a seventh perching with wings raised.

There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing," both with loops, and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines (lines 13-14) and across the bottom. Curving lines left of the second stanza (lines 7-10), which hint at vines in other copies, are very faint in this copy.

lg.l: When the green woods laugh with the voice of joy
And the dimpling stream runs laughing by,
When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
And the green hill laughs with the noise of it.
When the meadows laugh with lively green
And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,
When Mary and Susan and Emily.
With their sweet round mouths sing Ha, Ha, He,
When the painted birds laugh in the shade
Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread
Come live & be merry and join with me,
To sing the sweet chorus of Ha Ha, He.

desc.objtitle:
The School Boy,
Object 12 (Bentley 53, Erdman 53, Keynes 53)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text are three boys playing a game of marbles on a bare patch of ground. To the right of the boys is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. On the vines are four other children, nude or in tights: (bottom to top) one—long-haired and thus perhaps a girl—standing with arms raised, two boys(?) climbing, and another boy(?) sitting and reading. In the left margin is another elaborate vine with a large bird perched near its top, left of the first stanza. There would appear to be a figure standing in this vine, left of the fourth stanza. The tinting of the text area suggests the sky at sunrise (see "summer morn," line 3).

component.illusobjdesc: The short-haired boy in tights on the left kneels on the ground with his arm down, as if poised to shoot a marble in the game of marbles that he and the other children present are playing.

The short-haired (perhaps curly-haired) boy in tights in the middle kneels, leaning forward, with his arms braced to support his weight. His left leg is bent under him; his right leg is extended to the left. He looks down toward the hand of the boy to the left who is poised to shoot a marble.

The right-most child—apparently male—in the group below the text has long hair and wears tights. He is sitting, bending sharply forward with head and arms down. Though facing left, he appears to be looking down at the ground rather than at the game.

A long-haired (and nude) girl or boy stands at the intersection of two vines, perhaps in the process of climbing them (like the figure just above it). The left-facing figure's head is thrown sharply back, its arms are raised vertically to hold onto the vines above its head, and its weight is on its extended left leg. Its arms fuse with the plant.

A short-haired boy in tights climbs in the intertwining vines that extend up the right margin. Facing right, he raises his arms vertically to hold onto the vines over his head. His right leg is drawn up toward his body; his left leg is extended along the vine.

A child either in flesh-colored tights or nude, probably a boy though other identifying features are not shown, climbs the vine. His arms are raised vertically to cling to the vines over his head. His legs are spread wide, and he appears to wear shoes.
Facing right, a child (probably male), either in flesh-colored tights or nude, sits in a curve at the top of a vine in the right margin. He holds, and appears to be reading, a book.
The figure sitting at the top of the vines on the right appears to be reading an open book.
A figure wearing a gown stands in the vine left of the fourth stanza. She(?) faces forward, with her head turned to the right.
A bird with long forked tail and wings partially spread perches in the vegetation to the left of the first stanza.

Behind the right-most figure below the text is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation—perhaps grass—and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. The vines have numerous tendrils and leaves and at least one large cluster of fruit, to the right of line 21.
Rooted at lower left, a slender tree with leaves extends up the left margin and ends opposite line 8(?). An intertwined vine climbs the tree, with one loop left of the fifth stanza.
The tinting of the text area suggests the sky at sunrise (see "summer morn," line 3).
Three children play a game of marbles. Four marbles are visible on the ground beneath the right-most child.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 2) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal trees and vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration). Tendrils from the vines in the right margin—part of the main illustration—are extended into some of the spaces left by short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 2) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration).

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
O! what sweet company.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away;
Under a cruel eye outworn.
The little ones spend the day.
In sighing and dismay.
Ah! then at times I drooping sit.
And spend many an anxious hour.
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Nor sit in learnings bower.
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing.
How can a child when fears annoy.
But droop his tender wing,
And forget his youthful spring.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And blossoms blown away.
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,
By sorrow and cares dismay.
How shall the summer arise in joy.
Or the summer fruits appear. (troy
Or how shall we gather what griefs des
Or bless the mellowing year.
When the blasts of winter appear.

desc.objtitle:
The Voice of the Ancient Bard,
Object 13 (Bentley 54, Erdman 54, Keynes 54)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned, bearded old man stands, playing a large harp, before an audience of perhaps two children—standing in the middle of the group—and six older youths. He may be the bard of the title. To the left stand two young females who embrace. To the right stand the two children and a group of three females who face the bard. At their feet, facing them, kneels another female. All the figures are gowned. The scene is set outdoors on a strip of slightly inclined grassy ground. A palm-like frond arches over the head of the figure at far right and the vine in the left margin of the text dangles down into this major design above the heads of the embracing couple. Blue and dark gray washes suggest a partially darkened sky, but with slight rosy tints upper right that might suggest a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At left stands an embracing couple. A young female faces away from the viewer with her visible arm raised vertically to hold the shoulder of her companion.
At left stands an embracing couple. The taller female has curly hair, perhaps drawn into a bun. She looks down at the other figure and holds her visible hand on her companion's buttocks.

A tall, bearded old man in a gown stands facing right as he plays a large triangular harp with a bent right arm and a raised left one. He may be the bard of the title. His right foot shows beneath the hem of his garment.

In the middle of the group, just right of the old man, stand two gowned children (distinctly shorter than their companions). The listening child to the left faces forward and looks up toward the bard. The child on the right faces right and looks up toward the threesome to the right.

At right stand three young gowned females, at least the one on the left with short hair, the others probably with long hair. They look toward and listen to the bard. The left-most of the three holds her arm, slightly bent, at her side and partly behind her back; the right-most faces left and bends her arm up to hold the arm of the middle figure. The central figure has left arm bent at the elbow and extended across her body. At their feet and facing away from the viewer kneels a fourth young female similarly dressed and coiffured. She looks toward the threesome rather than at the bard. Her left arm is bent upward, with her left hand raised and fingers spread apart.
Over the head of the figure at far right arches a palm-like frond.
The green tinting of the ground beneath the figures' feet suggests grass.
Blue and dark gray washes suggest a partially darkened sky, but with slight rosy tints upper right that might hint at a sunrise or sunset.
An old man, perhaps a bard, plays a large triangular harp that rests on the ground at his feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title (line 3) is a large, spiky leaf. A vine descends from the leaf down the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design. A vine right of lines 4-11 branches into three leaves on three long stems.

component.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title (line 3) is a large, spiky leaf. A vine descends from the leaf down the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design. A vine right of lines 4-11 branches into three leaves on three long stems.

lg.l: Youth of delight come hither,
And see the opening morn,
Image of truth new-born.
Doubt is fled & clouds of reason.
Dark disputes & artful teazing.
Folly is an endless maze,
Tangled roots perplex her ways,
How many have fallen there!
They stumble all night over bones of the dead;
And feel they know not what but care;
And wish to lead others when they should be led

desc.objtitle:
The Chimney Sweeper,
Object 14 (Bentley 12, Erdman 12, Keynes 12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration seems to depict chimney sweeper Tom Dacre's dream of liberation for himself and his fellow sweeps by an angel, who releases them from their "coffins of black" to run "naked" down a "green plain" and "wash in a river" (lines 14-18). (The river is not visible in this copy.) Against a background of grass(?) are twelve(?) small figures, including one adult and eleven(?) smaller children. At bottom right a gowned adult bends forward, reaching toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the coffins of the text. Across the rest of the bottom of the plate are nude figures standing or running with their arms raised in various positions. Two pairs are embracing. Behind the gowned adult a tree grows up the right margin and becomes visually linked to the interlinear decorations. The tinting of the lower part of the text area suggests a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The tinting of the lower part of the text area suggests a sunrise or sunset.

At bottom right a gowned adult, presumably the liberating angel of the text, bends forward, reaching toward, and holding the hand of, a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the "coffins" of the text (line 14).

At bottom right a gowned adult reaches down toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the "coffins" of the text (line 14). This small figure—probably a child—reaches up with the left arm to hold the adult's hand; the right arm is bent and braced against the coffin or earth. One leg, just emerging from underground, is bent at the knee. The child looks up to the adult.
The dark patch under the child emerging (with the adult's help) from the earth may be a grave or one of the "coffins" of the text (line 14).

A pair of nude figures (the ninth and tenth figures from the left) stands with their arms raised at 135 degrees; they may be holding hands. They are most likely two of the liberated nude boys of Tom Dacre's dream in the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
The seventh and eighth standing figures from the left embrace. These are presumably two of the naked liberated chimney sweepers of the text.

The fifth and sixth figures from the left in the group bottom left run with their arms raised. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
The third and fourth figures from the left in the group bottom left face each other and embrace, with legs spread apart. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text.

The first and second figures from the left in the group bottom left appear to be running with arms raised vertically or at 135 degrees. In this copy, the second figure from the left can hardly be discerned. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
A thin, leafy, serpentine tree grows up the right margin, ending to the right of the fifth stanza of the poem.
Green washes below the group of liberated boys suggest the "green [i.e., grassy?] plain" of the text (line 17). Plants, perhaps a hedge or bushes, rise behind the figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms (leaves, vines, etc.) and at least five tiny human figures: a chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot and walking to the right within the "C" of the title (line 2), a pair of figures sitting on the tendril above "Sweeper" in the title, and a pair of figures sitting on the vine or tree right of lines 15-17. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title. A loopy vine descends in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: In the "C" of "Chimney" in the title (line 2) is a tiny figure that may be a right-facing chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot.

A pair of tiny figures sit on the tendril above "Sweeper" in the title (and thus may be child chimney sweeps [line 2]). The one on the left has one arm raised vertically and the other horizontally. The figure on the right, facing left, has at least one arm extended.

A pair of figures (child chimney sweepers?) face each other in the vine, or branches of a tree, right of lines 15-17. The figure on the left stands or leans against the vegetation at his or her back; his or her companion sits. Both have arms raised.

The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms. The capital letters of the title (line 2) and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title. A loopy vine descends in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines. The vegetation right of lines 15-17, in which two figures are pictured, may be a tree.

lg.l: When my mother died I was very young.
And my father sold me while yet my tongue
Could scarcely cry weep weep weep weep.
So your chimneys I sweep & in soot I sleep.
Theres little Tom Dacre. who cried when his head
That curl'd like a lambs back, was shav'd. so I said.
Hush Tom never mind it. for when your head's bare.
You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair.
And so he was quiet, & that very night.
As Tom was a sleeping he had such a sight,
That thousands of sweepers Dick. Joe Ned & Jack
Were all of them lock'd up in coffins of black,
And by came an Angel who had a bright key.
And he open'd the coffins & set them all free.
run
Then down a green plain leaping laughing they rThe "r" at the end of line 18 may be the first letter of "run". Lacking sufficient space for the word, Blake etched it above line 18 (line 17).
And wash in a river and shine in the Sun.
Then naked & white, all their bags left behind.
They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind.
And the Angel told Tom if he'd be a good boy,
He'd have God for his father & never want joy,
And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark
And got with our bags & our brushes to work.
Tho' the morning was cold, Tom was happy & warm,
So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

desc.objtitle:
The Lamb,
Object 15 (Bentley 8, Erdman 8, Keynes 8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a grassy(?) landscape, a nude boy(?) with short, curly hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands. Behind the flock are a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left) and a cottage or barn (right) with an open doorway. On its thatched roof perch two birds, often identified as doves. Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout leaves and several loopy tendrils. Where the tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem, they are leafy. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas. Blue and gray washes suggest sky; yellow and pink washes hint at a sunrise or sunset.

He reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands. His head is bent slightly downward as he looks at the sheep.

The lamb appears to look up at the child.

A shadow cuts diagonally across the top left corner of the door of the building. A triangular shadow appears bottom left.
Blue and gray washes suggest sky; yellow and pink washes hint at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Gave thee life & bid thee feed.
By the stream & o'er the mead;
Gave thee clothing of delight,
Softest clothing wooly bright;
Gave thee such a tender voice,
Making all the vales rejoice;
Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Little Lamb I'll tell thee,
Little Lamb I'll tell thee;
He is called by thy name,
For he calls himself a Lamb:
He is meek & he is mild,
He became a little child:
I a child & thou a lamb,
We are called by his name.
Little Lamb God bless thee,
Little Lamb God bless thee.

desc.objtitle:
HOLY THURSDAY,
Object 16 (Bentley 19, Erdman 19, Keynes 19)

objnote.p: Long, light pencil lines cross the text, with what may be a large X in the center of the text area. This lines were almost certainly not inscribed by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some hold one another around the waist or shoulder (clearest in the eighth pair from the left). Most of the boys wear hats. They are led by a pair of gowned adults, both with hats and carrying staffs or scepters. At the bottom of the plate a similar procession occurs, though with seven pairs of girls instead of nine of boys, walking left instead of right, and led by a single gowned female(?) figure who is holding something, probably a book. The girls wear dresses, possibly with aprons. The figures altogether represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-7). Blue wash behind the figures at top suggests sky, and yellow wash behind the figures at bottom may suggest sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some hold one another around the waist or shoulder (clearest in the eighth pair from the left). Others, such as the sixth pair, do not. Most of the boys wear hats or caps. Along with the figures at the bottom, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" (lines 4-6).

The procession of children is led by a pair of robed adults, probably male(?), both with hats, and carrying staffs or scepters. They are the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" (line 6).
The beadles at the head of the procession hold staffs or scepters, the "wands" (line 6) of the text.

Seven pairs of girls walk left, led by a single adult figure. The girls wear uniform dresses, some perhaps with aprons. They may be wearing hats or head coverings of some sort. Their positions are not always clear; one of the girls in the fifth pair from the right gestures with her hands. One of the girls in the fourth pair from the right may be holding something in her hand. Along with the figures at the top, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-7).
The procession of girls is led by a single gowned figure, probably female, who may be holding something, probably a book. The figure appears to be wearing a wig or cap.
The robed figure who is leading the procession may be wearing a cap or wig and holding something, probably a book.
Blue wash behind the figures at top suggests sky, and yellow wash behind the figures at bottom may suggest sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title (line 2) are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S," "D," and "Y" of "THURSDAY") and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird (below "into the" in line 7) or human figure (beneath "innocent" in line 11). Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves but including a bird perching on a vine, wings outspread, facing the viewer. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 9 and above "their" in line 11) or human figures (e.g., in the crook of the "L" of "HOLY" [line 2]) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

component.illusobjdesc: There is a tiny human figure, running or hovering with arms raised horizontally, beneath "innocent" in line 11. Some of the decorations are suggestive of human figures (e.g., in the crook of the "L" of "HOLY" [line 2]) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

There are birds beneath "into the" in line 7—flying to the right—and beneath "you drive" in line 15—perching and facing forward, with wings outspread, on a vine. The latter bird may be an eagle. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 9 and above "their" in line 11) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves.
