lg.l: Twas on a Holy Thursday their innocent faces clean
The children walking two & two in red & blue & green
(snow
Grey headed beadles walkd before with wands as white as
Till into the high dome of Pauls they like Thames waters flow
O what a multitude they seemd these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes was there but multitudes of lambs
Thousands of little boys & girls raising their innocent hands
Now like a mighty wind they raise to heaven the voice of song
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among
Beneath them sit the aged men wise guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door

desc.objtitle:
The Divine Image,
Object 17 (Bentley 18, Erdman 18, Keynes 18)

objnote.p: Some lightly-drawn and seemingly random pencil lines extend over the penultimate stanza of the text and into the design left of this stanza. These lines were almost certainly not drawn by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at right in the strip of grassy ground that runs across the bottom of the plate, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward flourish at top left. The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant, which the vine continues to climb until it terminates just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure. There are several human figures on and around the plants: (at top left) a gowned female with long hair walks right; a second gowned female, probably with long hair, floats behind her, pointing right; two figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer; (at bottom right) a gowned figure stands, with an arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a nude male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, perhaps a half-nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. The green coloring of the ground suggests grass; gray, rose, and blue tinting in and around text areas may indicate a dark sky near sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At top left, a gowned woman with long hair walks right; her right arm is drawn back behind her. Her left arm is at her side and she may be holding an object in her left hand, possibly a pitcher. Another gowned female, probably with long hair, hovers behind her, pointing right.
Two gowned figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer.

At bottom right, a long-haired (?) and haloed figure in a high-waisted gown stands, with an arm extended, touching the left hand of a short-haired, nude male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically toward the hand of the standing figure; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, perhaps a half-nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. Her right arm rests along the right side of her body. She wears only a skirt or loose pants. Her body faces forward, and her head appears to be turned slightly to the right and down. The nude male and female conceivably represent Adam and Eve; the standing gowned figure may be Christ.

A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at bottom right, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward curl at top left.

The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant (sending out occasional tendrils to the left, into the spaces left by short lines of the poem) until it terminates in a cluster of leaves that dangles just left of the title. (In other copies, the vine is connected to its final spray of leaves by several loops around the final curl of the flame-like plant, at the upper left of the illustration, but in this copy the vine disappears behind the gowned figures and mysteriously reappears left of the title.) A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure.
The flame-like plant and vine are apparently rooted at bottom left in the strip of grassy ground that runs across the bottom of the plate.
Gray, rose, and blue tinting in and around text areas may indicate a dark sky near sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: To Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
All pray in their distress:
And to these virtues of delight
Return their thankfulness.
For Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
Is God our father dear;
And Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
Is Man his child and care.
For Mercy has a human heart
Pity, a human face:
And Love, the human form divine.
And Peace, the human dress.
Then every man of every clime,
That prays in his distress,
Prays to the human form divine
Love Mercy Pity Peace.
And all must love the human form.
In heathen, turk or jew,
Where Mercy. Love & Pity dwell
There God is dwelling too.

desc.objtitle:
Night,
Object 18 (Bentley 20, Erdman 20, Keynes 20)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second branch of the tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title (line 2). Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. In some copies there is a second, smaller tree to the right of the tree and vine, but in this copy the remains of the second tree’s trunk look like a spray of leaves hanging down from the vine, and the second tree’s branches seem to grow from the vine or from the first tree. Just left of the trees, lower right, a lion lies in a cave with vegetation arching over it. There are winged angelic figures in the tree, one standing with wing outspread and one arm extended at top right, a second sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first, and a third hovering or standing on one foot just above the lion's den. Two birds perch on a branch right of line 6. In the left margin are other figures and objects (bottom to top): one gowned, standing on the shadowed ground and facing the third stanza; just above that, a figure with one arm raised; another, arms raised vertically (in some copies it appears to be standing on a sphere, but in this copy, the figure's gown forms a curl instead); just above that another, smaller, with wings and arms outspread. All the figures may be the angels described in the text (Object 18, line 14; Object 19, line 7). Above the top figure on the left, left of line 6, is a sphere (the sun or moon?); scattered across this same space in the left margin are nine dots, perhaps stars. Two small circles left of lines 15 and 16 may be additional stars or planets. The background coloring suggests dusk.

component.illusobjdesc: There are winged, gowned angelic figures in the tree, one winged standing with one arm extended at top right; a second, facing right, sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first; and a third, with arms raised horizontally, hovering or standing on one foot just above the lion's den.

In the left margin are other figures (bottom to top): one gowned, standing and facing right toward the third stanza; just above that, a figure with left arm raised; another, arms raised vertically, (in some copies it appears to be standing on a sphere, but in this copy, the figure's gown forms a curl instead); just above that another, with wings and arms outspread. All the figures may be the angels described in the text (Object 18, line 14; Object 19, line 7).

Rooted at bottom right, a slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title (line 2)—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second branch of the tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. In some copies there is a second, smaller tree to the right of the tree and vine, but in this copy the remains of the second tree’s trunk look like a spray of leaves hanging down from the vine, and the second tree’s branches seem to grow from the vine or from the first tree. Some indeterminate vegetation extends in an arch over the cave, lower right.
Green coloring at the bottom of the plate suggests grass.
In the hill or bank at right is a cave.
Two birds perch on a limb right of line 6.
A lion lies facing forward in a cave.

In the left margin above the figures is a small circle, probably representing a sphere. It may be the moon or the sun. Below the sphere are nine scattered dots that may represent stars. Two very small circles left of lines 15 and 16 may be additional stars or planets.
The background coloring suggests dusk or "Night."

lg.l: Night

component.illusobjdesc: The style of lettering in the title integrates it into the tree.

lg.l: The sun descending in the west.
The evening star does shine.
The birds are silent in their nest.
And I must seek for mine,
The moon like a flower.
In heavens high bower;
With silent delight.
Sits and smiles on the night.
Farewell green fields and happy groves,
Where flocks have took delight;
Where lambs have nibbled. silent moves
The feet of angels bright;
Unseen they pour blessing,
And joy without ceasing,
On each bud and blossom.,
And each sleeping bosom.
They look in every thoughtless nest,
Where birds are coverd warm;
They visit caves of every beast,
To keep them all from harm;
If they see any weeping.
That should have been sleeping
They pour sleep on their head
And sit down by their bed.

desc.objtitle:
Night (continued),
Object 19 (Bentley 21, Erdman 21, Keynes 21)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. On the ground, in front of a backdrop of plants, five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To the left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right; the one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward; the one to the right looks left(?). All five figures have haloes and may be the angels mentioned in the text. In the vine-encircled tree trunk in the left margin are two other gowned female figures; these do not have haloes but may also be angels. The lowest stands on a limb of the tree and has one arm raised vertically; the top-most stands facing forward.

component.illusobjdesc: Five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To the left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right; the one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward; the one to the right looks left(?). All five figures have haloes and may be the angels mentioned in the text (Object 18, line 14; Object 19, line 7).

In the tree trunk in the left margin are two gowned female figures, perhaps the angels mentioned in the text. The lowest figure stands on a limb and raises one arm vertically. The top-most may be standing or hovering and would appear to face forward. Her left arm is at her side.

A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. Five figures stand on the grass against a backdrop of plants or other vegetation.
Long horizontal lines and blue tinting just above the bottom margin of the plate suggests a body of water, possibly a river or lake.
The crepuscular tinting in text areas and along the right margin, coupled with the dark green coloring of the foliage, suggest the poem's title ("Night" [Object 18, line 2]) or at least dusk.

lg.l: When wolves and tygers howl for preyOnly fragments of the final letter of "howl" printed.
They pitying stand and weep;
Seeking to drive their thirst away,
And keep them from the sheep.
But if they rush dreadful;
The angels most heedful,
Recieve each mild spirit.
New worlds to inherit.
And there the lions ruddy eyes,
Shall flow with tears of gold:
And pitying the tender cries,
And walking round the fold:
Saying: wrath by his meekness
And by his health. sickness.
Is driven away.
From our immortal day.
And now beside thee bleating lamb.
I can lie down and sleep;
Or think on him who bore thy name
Grase after thee and weep.
For wash'd in lifes river.
My bright mane for ever.
Shall shine like the gold.
As I guard o'er the fold.

desc.objtitle:
A Dream,
Object 20 (Bentley 26, Erdman 26, Keynes 26)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title (line 2) sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?). In front of the tree stands a figure, robed, wearing a hat, and holding a staff—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form. He is one of four small human figures on the plate. The other three are in the area of the title: lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; sitting, perhaps reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and floating or flying, with arms raised horizontally, between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream." The animal life of the poem appears in similarly tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) to the right of line 5 and another (very indistinct) crawling beneath the "her" in line 10; a (similarly indistinct) worm or caterpillar nestled in the lower right sprigs of the vegetation right of line 7; and winged beetles(?) (lines 20-21) flying right of lines 6 and 19 (the former is clearer in other copies). A bird, perhaps an eagle, unmentioned in the text, spreads its wings above "dream" in line 3.

component.illusobjdesc: In front of the tree in the bottom right corner stands a figure, robed, wearing a hat, and holding a staff in his(?) right hand, a lantern(?) in his left—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form.

There are three tiny figures in the area of the title (line 2): one lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; a second sitting, facing left, probably reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and a third hovering or flying with legs spread apart and arms raised horizontally between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream."

The insect life of the poem appears in tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) to the right of line 5 and another (very indistinct) crawling beneath the "her" in line 10; a (similarly indistinct) worm or caterpillar nestled in the lower right sprigs of the vegetation right of line 7; and winged beetles(?) (lines 20-21) flying right of lines 6 and 19 (the former is clearer in other copies). The human figure lower right may be the anthropomorphic form of the "glow-worm" (line 16).
A bird, perhaps an eagle, soars just below the space between "A" and "Dream" in the title (line 2).

Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title (line 2) sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?).
The watchman in the lower right corner may be holding a staff in his right hand and a lantern in his left. He seems to be wearing a hat.
The coloring of the text area suggests the sky.

lg.l: Once a dream did weave a shade.
O'er my Angel-guarded bed
That an Emmet lost it's way,
Where on grass methought I lay.
Troubled wilderd and folorn"folorn": i.e., "forlorn"
Dark benighted travel-worn,
Over many a tangled spray.
All heart-broke I heard her say.
O my children! do they cry,
Do they hear their father sigh.
Now they look abroad to see,
Now return and weep for me.
Pitying I drop'd a tear;
But I saw a glow-worm near;
Who replied. What wailing wight
Calls the watchman of the night.
I am set to light the ground,
While the beetle goes his round:
Follow now the beetles hum,
Little wanderer hie thee home.

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG,
Object 21 (Bentley 16, Erdman 16, Keynes 16)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. There are three figures in the letters "A," "C," and "D" of the title (line 2); five in the left margin; and five in the right.

component.illusobjdesc: There are three figures in the letters of the title: a piper, facing left, playing as he leans against the left side of the "A" (line 2); a figure, probably facing right, sitting inside the "C," possibly wearing a small hat and holding something (an infant?) upright; and a figure, facing forward, standing inside the "D."
A piper plays his pipe as he leans against the letter "A" in the title (line 2). A figure sitting inside the "C" may be wearing a small hat.

There are five figures in the left margin (top to bottom): a gowned woman(?) standing with her left arm raised vertically, and her other arm at her side, beside the second stanza; a hovering figure with arms raised next to "Hover" (line 12), and just beneath it a sitting figure; a seated, hunched over, gowned figure, with head lowered, left of the fifth stanza, and an upright figure left of the sixth stanza, standing or walking toward the right, with one or both arms raised.

There are five figures visible in the right margin (top to bottom): a gowned figure seated, with head down, right of line 5; a gowned female(?) figure lying horizontally, arm extended, in the flame-like vegetation to the right of lines 6 and 7; a figure seated facing left on a vine right of lines 16-17 with one arm behind its back and braced against the vine; a figure walking right at the end of lines 17-18; and a figure to the right of line 20-22, bent over facing right with one arm down as if braced for clambering up the vine.

Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. The dominant form is perhaps the vegetation with flame-like leaves that swirls in the spaces of the right margin (with a more conventional leaf or two at bottom right), underneath the title, and down the left margin. Tendrils extending from both margins help separate the stanzas from one another. The vine right of the final stanza on the plate has several loops suggesting a spiral. The vine full of leaves and flowers(?) that extends across the top of the plate above the title and fills the top right corner and the space right of the first stanza is distinct from the flame-like vegetation that dominates the rest of the plate. Extensions of letters in the title (line 2) contribute to both forms of vegetation: the initial "A" and "C" to the vine above, the "S" to both. In the text of the poem, occasional letters have modest decorative extensions, and there are a few bits of stray decorative vegetation.
The background colors on the plate suggest the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.
There is a low cliff of earth left of lines 21-26.

lg.l: Sweet dreams form a shade.
O'er my lovely infants head.
Sweet dreams of pleasant streams,
By happy silent moony beams
Sweet sleep with soft down,
Weave thy brows an infant crown.
Sweet sleep Angel mild,
Hover o'er my happy child.
Sweet smiles in the night,
Hover over my delight.
Sweet smiles Mothers smiles
All the livelong night beguiles.
Sweet moans. dovelike sighs.
Chase not slumber from thy eyes,
Sweet moans. sweeter smiles.
All the dovelike moans beguiles.
Sleep sleep happy child.
All creation slept and smil'd.
Sleep sleep. happy sleep.
While o'er thee thy mother weep
Sweet babe in thy face.
Holy image I can trace.
Sweet babe once like thee.
Thy maker lay and wept for me

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG (continued),
Object 22 (Bentley 17, Erdman 17, Keynes 17)

illustration.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother dressed in a high-waisted gown and cap or headdress of some sort leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a hooded wicker cradle. The infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8). A carpet with a complex pattern covers the floor, and dark fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother, dressed in a high-waisted gown and cap, scarf, or headdress of some sort, leans over an infant in a cradle. She faces right and looks at the infant; at least her right arm, and probably her left, are folded in front of her.

A nurse or mother leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a cradle. The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the smiling infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8).
The infant sleeps beneath a blanket and/or sheet. The configuration of the pillow suggests a halo.
An infant sleeps in a wicker cradle. The cradle has handles (one fully visible on the front edge, and one partially obscured on the far edge) and a hood that arches over the infant's head.
A carpet with an elaborate pattern covers the floor.
Dark fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.
The mother or nurse sits in a curved-back chair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous plate reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the left margin and beneath the text. In the left margin there are four human figures: beside the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands or walks with an infant in her arms; left of lines 6-7 is a running or leaping figure with arms raised horizontally; and left of line 8 is a small gowned figure facing, and perhaps walking, left with one arm extended.

component.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous plate reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the right margin and beneath the text. Two of these are extensions of letters in the text: the "S" of "Smiles" (line 6) and the "p" of "peace" (line 9).
Left of the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands or walks, facing right, with an infant in her arms.
Left of lines 6-7, a small figure strides or leaps or hovers in the air, facing right. Its legs are spread apart and its arms raised horizontally.
A tiny figure, perhaps gowned, hovers or walks to the left just left of line 8. This may be the "infant" referenced in the first word of line 8. Its arm is extended.
The coloring of the text area hints at sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Wept for me for thee for all.
When he was an infant small.
Thou his image ever see.
Heavenly face that smiles on thee.
Smiles on thee on me on all.
Who became an infant small,
Infant smiles are his own smiles.
Heaven & earth to peace beguiles

desc.objtitle:
The Blossom,
Object 23 (Bentley 11, Erdman 11, Keynes 11)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides. In its upper reaches there is a circle of eight figures (clockwise from the far right): (1) a nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically; (2) a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sitting on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2); (3) she seems to be holding an infant in her arms; (4) to her left, a nude winged figure, kneeling or sitting, facing left and probably reading or writing in a book or tablet; (5 and 6) far left, two winged figures who fly facing one another (one facing away from, and the other facing toward, the viewer); (7 and 8) and a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). All the figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central lower pair (2 and 3 above) may be the female blossom who addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. The tinting of the text area suggests a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of eight figures: at far right is a forward-facing nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically, its left foot forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sits on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2). She may be holding an infant in her arms. Her extended right foot is prominent. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, this pair may be the female blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like blossom is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged female(?) sitting on the blossom just above the "som" of "Blossom" (line 2) may be holding an infant in her arms. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant may represent one of those birds.

The human figures in the plant probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant(?) may represent one of those birds.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. Above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2) is a winged figure, nude(?), kneeling or sitting, facing left and perhaps reading or writing in a book or tablet resting just to the left of the figure. In this copy, we can see the right foot emerging from beneath the left thigh; hence, the figure's legs are crossed.
The small winged figure above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2) reads or writes in a book or tablet immediately to the left of this figure.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces away from the viewer is perhaps male(?). His arms are raised horizontally, and his legs are spread.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces forward is probably another nude putto, but might be female. Its arms are raised at 45 degrees, both to the right, and its legs are together, left forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At top center is a second pair of winged nude figures facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). At least one leg of the figure on the left is extended backward. This figure is either sitting or kneeling; the figure on the right is more clearly kneeling.

Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides. The reddish coloring of the vertical portion underscores its flame-like nature. Most of the horizontal portions just above the bottom margin of the plate, however, are colored green. Gray and rose are the dominant colors in the upper reaches of the plant. Part of the etching border top left has been developed into a branch of the giant plant, particularly in the top left corner.
The tinting of the text area hints at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Merry Merry Sparrow
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Sees you swift as arrow
Seek your cradle narrow
Near my Bosom.
Pretty Pretty Robin
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Hears you sobbing sobbing
Pretty Pretty Robin
Near my Bosom.

desc.objtitle:
Nurse's Song Nurses Song,
Object 24 (Bentley 24, Erdman 24, Keynes 24)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the bottom, under the (lower?) limb of a tree with a few leaves, seven children—four boys(?) in tight-fitting garments and three girls(?) in gowns—hold hands and play, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. The two children furthest left stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth, between them. A matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title (line 2), sits on the ground against the trunk and reads a book in her lap. To the right is a second tree, slimmer and more obviously leafy, with a vine around its lower trunk. There are two "hills" (line 14) in the background and shadows across the foreground in front of the nurse. The coloring of the text area above suggests a sunset (line 7).

component.illusobjdesc: Seven children hold hands and play vigorously, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. Clockwise from the left: The two children furthest left (a girl[?] and a short-haired boy) stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth used in a game, between them; a girl raises her arms horizontally and faces right with legs outspread; a boy raises his arms higher, as does the long-haired girl to the right of him, whose leg is extended behind her; holding her hand, a boy runs left and reaches forward to hold the hand of another running or striding boy, left leg extended behind him, who raises his free left hand as he moves left and back, perhaps toward the opening between the pair furthest left. All the girls wear gowns; all the boys wear tight-fitting garments. These are the "little ones" who "leaped & shouted & laugh'd" (line 17) and remonstrate with the nurse in the poem.

Facing right, a matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title who remonstrates with the children of the poem, sits on the ground or a low seat against the trunk of a tree and reads a book that she holds in her lap.

On the left is the trunk of a tree whose lowermost branch, with a few leaves, spreads over the nurse who sits at the base of its trunk. On the right is a second tree, slimmer, with more leafy branches visible and a vine climbing up its trunk. Between the trees is the grassy "green" of line 3.
There are two "hills" (line 14) in the background and shadows in the foreground. The coloring of the text area suggests the sunset alluded to in the text, line 7.
The nurse reads a book that she holds in her lap.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On this plate the interlinear designs are especially dense around the title, in the margins, and between the three stanzas. The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, loops, and leaves, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g" (line 2). Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 6. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin. Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," climbing the left stroke and sitting on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one reaching downward through the following "u," joining hands with another who reaches up from below; one leaning against or sitting on the "S" of "Song"; two beneath "Song" on the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one reclining, with right arm raised horizontally and the left arm drawn back for support, on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 4 and another(?) on the leafy structure at the end of line 6.

component.illusobjdesc: Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation. Clockwise from top left: two on the "N" of "Nurse's" (line 2), one (nude?) climbing the left stroke and the other sitting, facing right, on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one hovering in the following "u," reaching downward and joining hands with another who reaches up from below, where he/she is seated, facing left, on the end of the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one facing left and leaning, with one leg drawn up, against the "S" of "Song"; near the right end of the long horizontal descender of the "g," two reclining; one, right arm raised horizontally and the left arm drawn back for support, reclining on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 4 and another(?) on the leafy structure at the end of line 6.

The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g" (line 2). There are several long, slender leaves (the descender on the "g," for instance), and there are a number of shorter, broader leaves as well. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 6. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin.
A few lines may represent water into which the branches of the willow descend.

lg.l: When the voices of children are heard on the green
And laughing is heard on the hill,
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still
Then come home my children the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Come come leave off play, and let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No no let us play, for it is yet day
And we cannot go to sleep
Besides in the sky, the little birds fly
And the hills are all coverd with sheep
Well well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed
The little ones leaped & shouted & laugh'd
And all the hills ecchoed

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy lost,
Object 25 (Bentley 13, Erdman 13, Keynes 13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 2), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5). A tree rises on the right and branches over the child's head.

component.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy with curly hair and wearing a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light on the left. A mark on his left foot in this copy may indicate the border of a shoe, indicating that he may be wearing shoes. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 2). He runs or walks to the left.
A tree rises on the right and branches over the child's head.
The boy wears a hat. In other copies, this suggests a halo more than in this copy.
The boy wanders at night in the darkness.

A small boy holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. The white triangle is surrounded with radiating lines, presumably indicating radiance or beams of light. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 2), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10; i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six gowned angels, four winged. The letters of the title sprout vegetative extensions, and there are other bits of vegetation amidst the angels (notably at the bottom), between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There are also two seated figures in the title letters, one facing left on the "L" of "Little" and one with raised arm in the "B" of "Boy" (line 2). There may be another figure lying in the lower curve of this "B." There are four flying birds and a swan or duck among the lines of the title and the first stanza.

component.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, all perhaps female. They are symmetrically arranged, two beside each stanza and two, aligned foot to foot, beneath. They all seem to be gowned, and the four in the right and left margins have wings. The two in the right margin have their arms at their sides; the two wingless figures below float or fly horizontally with one arm raised (with banners or flags of drapery arranged symmetrically); the lower figure in the left margin has its arms by its side; the upper figure on that side faces right, has its left arm raised vertically, and may be pointing to the scene above.

A tiny human figure sits, facing left, on the upper stroke in the initial "L" of "Little" in the title (line 2). At least one arm is raised horizontally and at least one leg dangles downward. The figure may be holding an object in its hand. Defined by a stroke between the figure's hand and its face, the object may be a pipe which the figure may be playing.

A tiny human figure sits, facing left, at the bottom of the "B" of "Boy" in the title (line 2). One arm is raised at 135 degrees; one leg may be bent at the knee. There may be another figure lying in the lower curve of this "B."

Four birds fly among the lines of the title and the first stanza: over "lost" in the title (line 2), over "where" and "going" in line 3, and after "fast" in line 4. There is a swan or duck, facing right, above the "y" of "Boy" (line 2).

The letters of the title (line 2) sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above most of the title. The "y" of "Boy" is extended, and an unattached clump of plant-like decoration surrounds the right end of the title. There are other bits of leafy (and/or flowery) vegetation around the two figures at the bottom, between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There is a particularly loopy, leafy tendril after line 6 and between the two stanzas. The plant right of the title includes a grain tassel or catkin.

A tiny human figure sits, facing left, on the upper stroke in the initial "L" of "Little" in the title (line 2). The object in its hand, which is defined by a stroke between the figure's hand and its face, may be a pipe.
The blue and gray tinting in the text area suggest that the angelic figures are hovering in the night sky.

lg.l: Father. father. where are you going
O do not walk so fast,
Speak father, speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost,
The night was dark no father was there
The child was wet with dew.
The mire was deep, & the child did weep
And away the vapour flew

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Found,
Object 26 (Bentley 14, Erdman 14, Keynes 14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a dark landscape dominated by the trunks of three large trees, a long-haired adult figure, visually ambiguous in gender but male according to the text, dressed in a high-waisted long gown holds the arm of a gowned child. The two figures look at one another as they walk forward, on rather barren (but perhaps grassy) ground, toward the viewer. The child raises his right arm to hold the adult's arm. The adult figure has a golden area around his head that suggests a halo. A dark area around the child's head, as on the previous plate, suggests a hat or halo. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

component.illusobjdesc: A haloed, long-haired adult figure in a high-waisted long gown—visually ambiguous in gender though the reference to "God . . . like his father" (lines 5-6) suggests that he is male—walks beside a boy whose arm he holds (he holds his opposite arm by his side). If this is God, it is very probably Christ, given the similarities between this figure and several of Blake's other representations of Christ. Both feet are exposed; his left foot is forward. He looks down toward the boy.

The two figures walk forward toward the viewer. A gowned male child with short, curly hair walks forward toward the viewer beside a similarly dressed adult whose arm he holds and up at whom he looks. The child raises his left arm at 45 degrees, his right at 135 degrees. He is stepping forward with his right leg. A dark area around the child's head, similar to what we see on the previous plate, suggests a hat or halo. Judging from the previous plate, the boy may be wearing shoes. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

A dark landscape—the "lonely dale" (line 9) of the text—is dominated by three large and ominous tree trunks—two left and one right—without visible leaves or other vegetation. The trunks arch to create a kind of dark tunnel in which the two figures walk.
The darkness suggests that the time is still the "night" (Object 21, line 7) specified in "The Little Boy lost" (Object 21, line 2).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit flies or hovers with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title and into the left margin; another group of detached vegetative decorations fills the space below the poem and up the right margin to the angelic spirit. Another loopy vine descends in the left margin.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit, probably female, floats with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. She looks sharply upward, as if at the design above. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. This may be the child's "mother" (line 8) to whom he is led.

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title. The capital letters of the title all have such extensions. The "y" of "Boy" extends far to the left and down the left margin, and the vertical stroke of the "d" of "Found" (line 2) is extravagantly extended to fill the space above the angel. Another cluster of vine-like decorations begins in the right margin in front of the legs of the angel and extends downward (with at least one leaf) into the space below the poem.
A few blue, pink, and yellow washes in the text area suggest the sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: The little boy lost in the lonely fen.
Led by the wand'ring light,
Began to cry, but God ever nigh.
Appeard like his father in white.
He kissed the child & by the hand led
And to his mother brought,
Who in sorrow pale thro' the lonely dale
Her little boy weeping sought.
